{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3375901,"name":"Noam Novo","username":"Noam6738","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/noam6738/{size}/221795_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T14:38:11.798Z","cooked":"

Hello there!

Quick question:
How are you all saving your CAD files? Are you using any specific format patterns or organization techniques? I’m looking for some best practices to streamline our CAD file management. Any tips or insights would be greatly appreciated!

Example of saving format:

 SP1-> shooter,plate number 1
","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T15:10:07.253Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":178,"reads":394,"readers_count":393,"score":1013.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464789,"topic_slug":"what-names-do-you-save-your-cad-files-under","display_username":"Noam Novo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/frc-orbit-1690-2024-robot-cad-release/464838/21","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"FRC Orbit 1690 2024 Robot CAD Release","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65492,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Solidworks user ;)"},"post_url":"/t/what-names-do-you-save-your-cad-files-under/464789/1","custom_user_title":"Solidworks user ;)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3375912,"name":"Ian","username":"TrackpadCAD","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/f0a364/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T14:50:47.946Z","cooked":"

XXX-XXX. The top level assemblies would be 100-000, 200-000, 300-000, etc. Then the sub-assemblies inside 100-000 would be 110-000, 120-000, 130-000, etc. Parts are then counted up within the assemblies, so a part inside 110-000 would be 110-001, 110-002, 110-003, etc. These number designations are then followed with a descriptive name. Generic parts (like a 1/2" hex bearing for example) are stored in a separate project. I’m fairly confident there’s a name / standard for this type of structure but I completely forgot what it is.

Inspired by: Part Numbering and Nomenclature | Team 254

Term I was looking for: Work breakdown structure - Wikipedia

My team used year_subassembly_description for the naming of most parts eg. 2024_shooter_top-plate
This has been helpful as searching for specific parts is much easier

(Team Number) - (Year) - (Type) - (## subassembly)(## part number or mini subassembly)

Type:
M - Master Sketch
A - Assembly
P - part
Example:

9999-2024-P-0102
9999-2024-A-01
9999-2024-A-0201

We have a presentation to explain it: CAD | Naming Conventions - Google Slides

TagYear-assembly number-part number_name or odentifier.

We also divide al sub assemblies in separate folders. It would look like this.
Assemblies numbers.
00-General
01-Chasis
02-Intake
03-Shooter
Etc…

The tag we use is LB from Lambot so part names would look like this:
LB24-00-03_Camera mount
LB24-01-08_Side plate
LB22-02-05_HexAxle
LB23-03-02_HoodPlate

We leave cots with their name since we have a library from where we pull all unchaged COTS, if for any reason a COTS part needs to be modified then it follows the same naming format.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T16:41:35.744Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":247,"readers_count":246,"score":64.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":464789,"topic_slug":"what-names-do-you-save-your-cad-files-under","display_username":"osofdez","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29869,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/what-names-do-you-save-your-cad-files-under/464789/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3375987,"name":"Everett33","username":"Everett33","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/everett33/{size}/5027_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T17:18:09.373Z","cooked":"

Our folder structure looks like this.
2024\Crescendo\500-Climber\501 - V1

  • Year
  • Season game name or off season prototype name etc. (Crescendo, Mini Bot, Etc.)
  • Subsystem (100-Chassis)(200-Shooter)(300-Intake)(400-Indexer)(500-Climber)(600-Upper Structure)(700-Trap)
  • Subsystem revision (501-V1, 501-V2, etc.)

The sub-folder in each subsystem indexes with revisions. We can pack-and-go the 501-V1 climber design to the 502-V2 folder and then make the tweaks we want while still retaining the 501-V1 design for reference.

An example file name would be 5660-FRC24-101-D001
101-A001 (Main assembly of the first revision folder)
101-A002 (sub-assembly of the first revision folder)
101-D001 (Custom Detail or part that is not cots, polycarbonate, aluminum, printed, etc.)
101-B001 (Bumper Part)

We use SolidWorks and Cache Cad

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T17:30:07.274Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":184,"readers_count":183,"score":176.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464789,"topic_slug":"what-names-do-you-save-your-cad-files-under","display_username":"Ian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":29971,"username":"gellnick","name":"Nyx","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gellnick/{size}/172273_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":11}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62888,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mecanum Enthusiast "},"post_url":"/t/what-names-do-you-save-your-cad-files-under/464789/10","custom_user_title":"Mecanum Enthusiast ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":9},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":6},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":17,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3376155,"name":"Ankur Raghavan","username":"Ankur-Raghavan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ankur-raghavan/{size}/207141_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T22:24:51.815Z","cooked":"

We use onshape so not directly comparable with other programs.

Inside our project, we have an assembly with the full robot and a folder for each subsystem. Inside the folder is an assembly for the subsystem and a part studio for each type of part. Usually CNC Plates, 3D prints, and shafts/spacers/tubing are the categories. Inside part studios, plates are named subsystem - function/descriptor - plate (ex: “Shooter Omni Plate”) and any generic/generated part is named subsystem - function/descriptor - tube/shaft/spacer - size (ex: Drivetrain Side Tube 2"x1"x17.5"). Chains/Belts are all generated in one part studio and named according to the number of teeth and pulley size on each end (ex: 18 - 30 - 174 links 25 chain).

COTS parts are inserted using MKCad so naming isn’t required for those.

We will have our cad cleaned up soon so you can see how badly we followed these rules

The most important thing with a convention is that people actually follow it

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":23,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T22:30:05.604Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":159,"readers_count":158,"score":56.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464789,"topic_slug":"what-names-do-you-save-your-cad-files-under","display_username":"Ian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50601,"username":"Ankur-Raghavan","name":"Ankur Raghavan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ankur-raghavan/{size}/207141_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62888,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mecanum Enthusiast "},"post_url":"/t/what-names-do-you-save-your-cad-files-under/464789/12","custom_user_title":"Mecanum Enthusiast ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3376164,"name":"Marshall Hamon","username":"Zekrim","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/z/b487fb/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T22:31:32.422Z","cooked":"

Four-character alphanumerical prefix (All caps) _ Part number (3 digits) _ Descriptive part name (no more than 20 characters) _ V#

Part numbers are assigned sequentially from 000. We use this system to make it easy to find files when looking through a file browser.

We only use _V# if it’s an iteration on a single part that makes it distinct from the previous part. We probably only have a few parts from the past 2 seasons, while we’ve been using this system that warranted this version suffix tag.

Whenever we do a full mechanism iteration, we assign it a new 4-letter prefix.

For example, our intake this year went from BTBR (Beter-Bar, when it was just a prototype we tried out) to INTK (Intake, when it was the mechanism) to (INK2) (Intake 2, when we did our only major iteration upon it.) When a mechanism has a new prefix, we reset its version suffix count.

Example parts/assemblies:

  • ARM2_000_FullAssembly.iam
  • INTK_005_PivotHexShaft.ipt

For COTS parts, we use the COTS part number instead. e.g. COTS_WCP-0940_KrakenX60.ipt

Were we to move to Onshape, we’d probably include some suffix to indicate whether the file is a part, assembly, or drawing. Inventor, like Solidworks, uses distinct part files for Parts, Assemblies, and Drawings.

We make sure that our drawings have the same file name as our parts/assemblies, to make them easier to find.

Finally, we use the MAIN prefix for files that don’t have to do with any particular mechanism (e.g. MAIN_000_MasterSketch.ipt or MAIN_001_FullRobotAssembly.iam)

This is incredibly valid. Last year, it was me, our mechanical lead, and our arm lead who complied with this convention. This year, it was everyone but our climb lead.

Running a practice CAD-a-thon/off-season robot where the stakes/time pressure are less high can help instill this habit in your designers.
